div1.p: This brief review, which appeared in the "Army Navy Journal," discusses Kelly's biography of Walter Reed.

div1.head: Book Review: Walter Reed and Yellow Fever, July 21, 1906
div1.p:
“Walter Reed and Yellow Fever” is the title of a
handsome volume published by McClure, Phillips and
Company, New York, in which the author, Prof. Howard
A. Kelly, of Johns Hopkins University, has embodied a
notably complete and admirably arranged biography of
the late Dr. Walter Reed, Med. Dept., U.S.A., whose
researches and discoveries with regard to the prevention
of yellow fever in Cuba during the Spanish War justly
rank among the noblest achievements of modern medical
science. Professor Kelly not only enjoyed the personal
friendship of Doctor Reed and was thus familiar with
his purposes, ambitions and ideals, but he has been aided
in the preparation of the present work by a vast collec-
tion of correspondence, documents, etc., placed at his
disposal by Mrs. Reed and various relatives and friends
of the lamented surgeon. The volume is therefore some-
thing more than a biography in that it presents a review
of the long and painstaking study of yellow fever to
which Doctor Reed assigned himself, together with a
graphic account of the processes and methods through
which his great final triumph was achieved. The work
is not only a valuable professional contribution to the
literature of the dreadful disease which Doctor Reed
finally conquered, but, in the personal sense, a sympa-
thetic and discriminating story of a noble and useful life.
